subject: Haptics issues
description_text:
Hello,

Mid game my haptics seem to lose telemetry and go into a constant vibration
so far it has done this with ac and acc games the pedals are plugged in via
usb and the haptics are plugged into a power bar. Is it a firmware issue? I
don’t know how to configure the haptics in sim hub unless you know how so I
don’t have to have the calibration software running in the background. The
haptics are quality but the reliability is questionable I can’t be having
these problems mid race and this has just started happening. Please get
back to me as soon as possible. I’m using the haptic pro only on brake and
throttle and there is activity with both pedals doing these vibration
stints.

conversations.body_text: Hi Daveyg G,  Just download version 9.9.3 of SIMHUB, then go to the Device section and add the SIMSONN device.           If you're using a Fanatec or Moza wheelbase, it's recommended to ensure that the base is properly grounded through your PC and connected to a valid household ground to eliminate electromagnetic interference. Additionally, connect the control box to any screw on the pedal using a green grounding wire. Please make sure the contact point is bare metal—painted surfaces may prevent proper conductivity.   https://github.com/SHWotever/SimHub/wiki/USB-Issues-Troubleshooting     https://support.gomezsimindustries.com/portal/en/kb/articles/understanding-emi-and-grounding

Hi Daveyg G,  Anti-interference Solutions: 1. Ensure your PC is properly grounded through a functional household ground line Some wall outlets only have two wires and lack a ground wire. This not only poses a safety risk but also prevents devices like Fanatec from discharging electromagnetic interference (EMI) effectively. 2. Use a wire to connect the metal housing of your wheel stand or base to the metal case of your PC This creates a shielding path that significantly improves the overall EMI resistance. 3. Connect a green shielded wire from the metal casing of the pedal control box to any metal screw on the pedal This ensures a solid electrical connection between the control box and the pedal to reduce signal drift and noise. 4. Use a USB isolator If interference persists, consider using a USB isolator to further block EMI transmission paths. ⚠ Note: Make sure all connection points are on bare metal surfaces. Painted or oxidized areas can result in poor grounding, reducing the effectiveness of the shielding.

Thanks for the information. I’ll let you know the results I installed the
wire to the new box like I specified I will let you know the results soon.
Thank you.

Hi Daveyg G,     Please take a photo of your entire haptic seat setup, and also include pictures of the power plugs for both your computer and the motion seat. This will help us further assess the situation.  We suspect that the issue may be caused by electromagnetic interference from the motion seat motors, which could be affecting the pedals and VAM Pro vibration motors. Under normal circumstances, the pedals and VAM Pro motors are very stable and rarely fail on their own.  It’s possible that your rig and computer are not properly grounded, which is a critical issue. If the system cannot effectively discharge interference or leakage through a household ground connection, it can lead to device instability—especially when motion seat motors or wheelbases are involved. It also poses potential safety hazards, such as induced voltages between 110V and 220V when touching the equipment, or frequent static shocks in winter.  If your computer or motion seat uses a two-prong plug, it almost certainly means the devices are not grounded. Even if you're using a three-prong outlet, if the wall socket's ground wire is not properly connected, it still does not provide true grounding.  We recommend:    Checking whether your PC and motion seat are using three-prong grounded plugs;    Verifying that your wall outlet is actually grounded (you can use a ground tester);    Avoiding USB hubs and connecting your device directly to the USB 3.0 ports on the back of your PC;    Optionally grounding your rig or seat by connecting it with a wire to the exposed metal part of your PC case.    Proper grounding will not only improve system stability but also ensure electrical safety. Feel free to share more photos, and we’ll assist you further.
On Wed, Jul 23, 2025 at 12:23 AM service@simsonn.com

Hi Daveyg G,  From your photo, I noticed several issues: First, all high-voltage power cables are placed directly above and below the brake pressure sensor, which can interfere with the weak voltage signal of the brake circuit, affecting the overall electromagnetic environment of the control box and motors. Second, your power outlet and power strip are two-prong types with no grounding. This means that all your devices are operating without a safe grounding environment, making interference with the VAM Pro vibration motor inevitable. In addition, if there is a short circuit or cable damage, there is a risk of accidental electric shock. Even Fanatec recommends that wall sockets and power strips have reliable grounding. At the very least, your computer should be properly grounded, and other devices can discharge interference through their USB connection to the PC.
